articles.headline: ‘This Broke Me’: Parkland Trial Reveals Depths of Families’ Sorrow
articles.snippet: The rare trial of a gunman in a mass shooting has underscored how massacres shatter families and communities over time.
articles.abstract: The rare trial of a gunman in a mass shooting has underscored how massacres shatter families and communities over time.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — Peter Wang’s mother has four tattoos memorializing her 15-year-old son, one inked on Feb. 14 each year since he was killed. Carmen Schentrup’s parents find sleep elusive. Nicholas Dworet’s mother hesitates every time someone asks her, “How many kids do you have?”

articles.headline: The Carried Interest Loophole Survives Another Political Battle
articles.snippet: The latest effort to narrow the preferential tax treatment used by private equity executives failed after Senator Kyrsten Sinema objected.
articles.abstract: The latest effort to narrow the preferential tax treatment used by private equity executives failed after Senator Kyrsten Sinema objected.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Once again, carried interest carried the day.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport, Emily Flitter and Kate Kelly

articles.headline: The Humbling of Coinbase
articles.snippet: In just over a year, the United States’ largest cryptocurrency exchange went from a triumphant public offering to a “crypto winter” of cost cutting and layoffs.
articles.abstract: In just over a year, the United States’ largest cryptocurrency exchange went from a triumphant public offering to a “crypto winter” of cost cutting and layoffs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Brian Armstrong, the chief executive of the largest cryptocurrency exchange in the United States, traveled across the world to make an announcement in early April: Coinbase was bringing crypto to India.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Democrats’ Long-Sought Plan for Lowering Drug Costs Is at Hand
articles.snippet: Empowering Medicare to negotiate prices directly with drug makers has been a Democratic goal for 30 years, one the pharmaceutical industry has fought ferociously.
articles.abstract: Empowering Medicare to negotiate prices directly with drug makers has been a Democratic goal for 30 years, one the pharmaceutical industry has fought ferociously.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For decades, as prescription drug costs have soared, Democrats have battled with the pharmaceutical industry in pursuit of an elusive goal: legislation that could drive down prices by allowing Medicare to negotiate directly with drug makers.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Rebecca Robbins

articles.headline: Good News on Jobs May Mean Bad News Later as Hiring Spree Defies Fed
articles.snippet: Employers hired rapidly and paid more in July, suggesting the Federal Reserve may have to remain aggressive in its effort to cool the economy.
articles.abstract: Employers hired rapidly and paid more in July, suggesting the Federal Reserve may have to remain aggressive in its effort to cool the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: America’s job market is remarkably strong, a report on Friday made clear, with unemployment at the lowest rate in half a century, wages rising fast and companies hiring at a breakneck pace.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: The Companies That Take Money Straight From Your Paycheck
articles.snippet: Some lenders and retailers have a pretty neat business model: You pay them before your wages ever hit your bank account. And sometimes they give you no choice.
articles.abstract: Some lenders and retailers have a pretty neat business model: You pay them before your wages ever hit your bank account. And sometimes they give you no choice.
articles.lead_paragraph: At any given time, millions of workers are overdue on at least one bill. But it is the rare employer that is late in cutting its paychecks or that bounces them altogether.

articles.headline: Don’t Expect Alex Jones’s Comeuppance to Stop Lies
articles.snippet: His success has inspired a new generation of conspiracy theorists, who have learned how to stay away from legal trouble.
articles.abstract: His success has inspired a new generation of conspiracy theorists, who have learned how to stay away from legal trouble.
articles.lead_paragraph: If it hadn’t been so excruciatingly sad, Alex Jones’s defamation trial might have been cathartic.

articles.headline: In Senate Battle, Democrats Defy Biden’s Low Standing (for Now)
articles.snippet: “The billion-dollar question,” as one Republican pollster put it, is whether Democratic candidates in crucial Senate races can continue to outpace the president’s unpopularity.
articles.abstract: “The billion-dollar question,” as one Republican pollster put it, is whether Democratic candidates in crucial Senate races can continue to outpace the president’s unpopularity.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — In a Senate split 50-50, Democrats on the campaign trail and in Congress have zero margin for error as the party tries to navigate a hostile political environment defined chiefly by President Biden’s albatross-like approval ratings.
articles.byline: By Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: How This Economic Moment Rewrites the Rules
articles.snippet: Jobs aplenty. Sizzling demand. If the United States is headed into a recession, it is taking an unusual route, with many markers of a boom.
articles.abstract: Jobs aplenty. Sizzling demand. If the United States is headed into a recession, it is taking an unusual route, with many markers of a boom.
articles.lead_paragraph: To understand the strange, conflicting signals being sent by the U.S. economy right now, it helps to look at Williston, N.D., in about 2010.

articles.headline: An Afrocentric Fashion Boom in the Streets and Presidential Palace
articles.snippet: The wardrobe of Francia Márquez, Colombia’s first Black vice president, is the creation of a young designer at the center of an Afro-Colombian fashion explosion.
articles.abstract: The wardrobe of Francia Márquez, Colombia’s first Black vice president, is the creation of a young designer at the center of an Afro-Colombian fashion explosion.
articles.lead_paragraph: CALI, Colombia — At a premier fashion event in the coastal city of Buenaventura this year, a pair of towering models strutted down the boardwalk, one in a red minidress with a fluted top inspired by an open seashell and the other wearing a blue-and-gold gown fit for a modern queen.

articles.headline: In Turbulent Times, Xi Builds a Security Fortress for China, and Himself
articles.snippet: Taiwan, Covid, “color revolutions,” the classroom: everywhere, China’s leader sees threats that foreign forces can exploit, and he has enlisted the whole nation to defend against them.
articles.abstract: Taiwan, Covid, “color revolutions,” the classroom: everywhere, China’s leader sees threats that foreign forces can exploit, and he has enlisted the whole nation to defend against them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over informal, private meals with American leaders, China’s Xi Jinping let his guard down a little. It was a decade ago, relations were less strained, and Mr. Xi, still cementing his power, hinted he worried about the Chinese Communist Party’s grip.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and Steven Lee Myers

articles.headline: Think 9% Inflation Is Bad? Try 90%.
articles.snippet: With the world grappling with rising prices, a tour through Argentina reveals that years of inflation can give rise to a truly bizarre economy.
articles.abstract: With the world grappling with rising prices, a tour through Argentina reveals that years of inflation can give rise to a truly bizarre economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Eduardo Rabuffetti is an Argentine who has been to the United States once, his 1999 honeymoon in Miami. Yet he probably knows the $100 bill better than most Americans.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas, Ana Lankes and Sebastián López Brach

articles.headline: Biden Is an Uneasy Champion on Abortion. Can He Lead the Fight in Post-Roe America?
articles.snippet: A practicing Catholic, President Biden has long sought a middle ground on abortion. But activists see the decision to overturn Roe v. Wade as a sign that Democrats have tiptoed too carefully around the issue.
articles.abstract: A practicing Catholic, President Biden has long sought a middle ground on abortion. But activists see the decision to overturn Roe v. Wade as a sign that Democrats have tiptoed too carefully around the issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s decision to end the constitutional right to an abortion in the United States after nearly 50 years has set in motion a generational struggle over Republican efforts to ban the procedure in states across the country.

articles.headline: Liz Cheney Is Ready to Lose. But She’s Not Ready to Quit.
articles.snippet: The Republican says her crusade to stop Donald J. Trump will continue — even if she loses her primary next week. Restoring a “very sick” G.O.P. will take years, she says, “if it can be healed.”
articles.abstract: The Republican says her crusade to stop Donald J. Trump will continue — even if she loses her primary next week. Restoring a “very sick” G.O.P. will take years, she says, “if it can be healed.”
articles.lead_paragraph: CHEYENNE, Wyo. — It was just over a month before her primary, but Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming was nowhere near the voters weighing her future.

articles.headline: Senate Passes Climate, Health and Tax Bill, With All Republicans Opposed
articles.snippet: The vote was a major victory for President Biden and Democrats, who are battling to maintain their slim House and Senate majorities in November’s midterm congressional elections.
articles.abstract: The vote was a major victory for President Biden and Democrats, who are battling to maintain their slim House and Senate majorities in November’s midterm congressional elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate passed legislation on Sunday that would make the most significant federal investment in history to counter climate change and lower the cost of prescription drugs, as Democrats banded together to push through major pieces of President Biden’s domestic agenda over unified Republican opposition.

articles.headline: In My Homeland, the Smell of Death on a Summer Afternoon
articles.snippet: In Ukraine, tragedies are a backdrop to everyday existence, piling up in numbers that seem inconceivable, an inescapable reality that feels like the very air in your lungs.
articles.abstract: In Ukraine, tragedies are a backdrop to everyday existence, piling up in numbers that seem inconceivable, an inescapable reality that feels like the very air in your lungs.
articles.lead_paragraph: LYSYCHANSK, Ukraine — There was a mass grave that held 300 people, and I was standing at its edge. The chalky body bags were piled up in the pit, exposed. One moment before, I was a different person, someone who never knew how wind smelled after it passed over the dead on a pleasant summer afternoon.

articles.headline: In an Unequal Economy, the Poor Face Inflation Now and Job Loss Later
articles.snippet: Americans with low incomes are pulling back from buying even as their richer counterparts keep spending — with potentially big consequences.
articles.abstract: Americans with low incomes are pulling back from buying even as their richer counterparts keep spending — with potentially big consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: Can Global Shipping Be Fixed? One Regulator Will Try.
articles.snippet: The Federal Maritime Commission, traditionally obscure, has been cast by Congress and the administration to help lead the campaign to tame inflation.
articles.abstract: The Federal Maritime Commission, traditionally obscure, has been cast by Congress and the administration to help lead the campaign to tame inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Daniel B. Maffei is at once a crucial player in the campaign to subdue inflation, and a figure virtually unknown outside the confines of his wonky Washington domain.

articles.headline: Axios Agrees to Sell Itself to Cox Enterprises for $525 Million
articles.snippet: The digital media company’s founders, Jim VandeHei, Mike Allen and Roy Schwartz, will continue to run the company.
articles.abstract: The digital media company’s founders, Jim VandeHei, Mike Allen and Roy Schwartz, will continue to run the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Axios, the digital media company that quickly gained traction since its founding five years ago with its distinctive bulletin-style scoops on the realms of politics, business and technology, said on Monday that it had agreed to sell itself to Cox Enterprises.
